I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  Early in 2011, the Ministry of Finance (MOF) asked the Asian Development Bank (ADB) 
for  policy  advice  to  develop  microfinance  in  Thailand  and  promote  financial  inclusion.  In 
response, ADB conducted inception and reconnaissance missions (30 March, 2–6 May, and     
12 May 2011). During a 11–25 July 2011 fact-finding mission, the Fiscal Policy Office (FPO) of 
MOF, the government’s executing agency, agreed on the proposed impact, outcome, outputs, 
implementation arrangements, cost, financing arrangements, and terms of reference as laid out 
in the approved concept paper. Meetings with the Bank of Thailand, microfinance providers, and 
other relevant stakeholders provided additional background information that confirmed the need 
for technical assistance (TA). The TA is included in the country operations business plan, 2011–
20131 under the country partnership strategy, 2007–20112 for Thailand. The project design and 
monitoring framework is in Appendix 1.3 
 
II.  ISSUES 
2.    Despite Thailand’s success in lowering the national incidence of poverty, significant 
pockets of subnational poverty remain. The government’s household socioeconomic survey,4 
used to estimate the poverty rate, shows, that the poverty incidence has continuously declined 
from 33.8% in 1988 to 9% in 2008, which is relatively low compared with other middle-income 
countries.  However,  the  aggregate  poverty  figure  masks  considerable  differences  in  the 
incidence of poverty across subnational regions and sectors.5 One important cause of poverty in 
these regions and an important characteristic of inequality in Thailand is lack of access to a 
variety of financial services.   
 
3.    While published data indicate that a large share of the population has access to financial 
services,6   the  degree  of  access  varies  considerably  across  income  groups.  Low-income 
families (the poorest 40% of households by income quintile) have access to a limited range of 
financial services and of lower quality services compared with middle- to high-income families 
(the richest 60% of households by income quintile). For example, about 38% of low-income 
families have only used one or two types of financial services, while another 16% do not use 
financial services at all. Almost 80% of middle- to high-income families use three or more types 
of financial services. Similarly, almost half of low-income households do not borrow compared 
with 27% of middle- to high-income households. About 28% of low-income households do not 
have access to savings products compared with 6% from middle- to high-income groups.

5  Poverty in Thailand is primarily a rural phenomenon with 88.5% of the country’s 5.3 million poor living in rural areas. 
Low-income families and poor families are heavily concentrated in agriculture, with almost half of the poor engaged 
in the agriculture sector. About 90% of the poor reside in rural areas; most are concentrated in the northeast (about 
58%)  and  the  north  (26%),  while  Bangkok  has  almost  no  poverty  (0.86%).  Source:  
K. Ariyapruchya, W. Sinswat, and N. Chutchotitham. 2007. The Wealth and Debt of Thai Households: Risk 
Management and Financial Access. Bank of Thailand Symposium 2007. Bangkok.

type, 85% had access to savings products, and 64% had borrowed from a financial institution (formal, semiformal, 
or informal) Source: K. Ariyapruchya, W. Sinswat, and N. Chutchotitham. 2007. The Wealth and Debt of Thai 
Households: Risk Management and Financial Access. Bank of Thailand Symposium 2007. Bangkok.

2 
4.    Microfinance development in Thailand began in 1966 when the government created the 
state-owned Bank for Agriculture and Agricultural Cooperatives (BAAC) to provide farm credits 
to  decrease  informal  debt.  In  1974,  the  Community  Development  Department  initiated 
community savings groups to provide savings and credit to households. Since this time, while 
the government continues to provide financial services to low-income households, the range of 
services is limited, and services are heavily subsidized and primarily focused on microcredit.  
 
5.    Microfinance in Thailand currently comprises three main categories: (i) formal and large 
microfinance  institutions—bank  and  nonbank  institutions  that  operate  under  prudential 
regulations—including  commercial  banks  and  special  financial  institutions;  (ii)  semiformal 
microfinance institutions operating under nonprudential regulations that are member-based and 
can capture savings and investments within communities (includes agricultural, savings, and 
credit  union  cooperatives;  registered  savings-for-production  groups;  and  village  and  urban 
revolving  funds;  and  (iii)  informal  independent  and  self-help  savings  and  credit  groups—
community and member-based organizations—that are often supported by external entities 
including nongovernment organizations (NGOs) or local government agencies. Government-
owned and subsidized special financial institutions have the dominant market share in the 
microfinance industry servicing low-income households.7 
 
6.    Because of strong government involvement in microfinance and a weak regulatory and 
supervisory framework for financial inclusion, entry of other microfinance institutions has been 
complicated,  difficult,  and  highly  restricted.  With  very  narrow  options  for  service  providers 
working under multiple regulators, private sector entry has been stifled, preventing necessary 
market competition, innovation, and service expansion. The key regulatory impediments to 
private sector participation include the interest rate ceilings for nonbanking financial institutions 
(NBFIs), licensing restrictions on MFI entry, and government-subsidized programs. Currently, 
microfinance licenses are only issued to domestic banks. Exemptions for preexisting nonprofit 
NGOs are considered on a case-by-case basis and stipulate that the institution restrict its 
activities to group lending only, inhibiting financially sustainable growth and preventing the 
development of a range of products and services beyond credit that clients need. The lack of 
private sector participation in microfinance has also limited efficiency and innovation. Thailand’s 
microfinance industry lags far behind those in other countries in the region.8 For example, 
mobile phone banking has grown rapidly in other emerging markets (such as the Philippines) 
but is essentially absent in Thailand. Microinsurance, critical to mitigating risks to the poor, is in 
its infancy but is growing fast with huge potential in Thailand. Over the last 4 years, a few 
providers have been making insurance accessible for farmers. In 2010, the government adopted 
a  microinsurance  strategy  and  is  committed  to  developing  the  subsector.  A  strengthened 
regulatory  framework  promoting  microinsurance  will  be  important  for  creating  an  enabling 
environment for the sector to grow.    
 
7.    Due  to  the  overabundance  of  inexpensive  credit  in  certain  areas  and  low  financial 
literacy, over-indebtedness and increased dependence on moneylenders has grown in some 
regions. In the current circumstances, financial service providers have little to no incentive to 
develop  important  financial  services  for  low-income  populations,  including  appropriately

Report, Thailand, 2010. 
8 Thailand ranked 50 out of 54 countries around the world in terms of its overall microfinance ranking and at the

3 
 
designed  and  priced  microinsurance,  remittance  services,  pensions,  and  mobile  banking 
services. The absence of a system for consumer protection and the lack of comprehensive 
financial education for low-income clients have further contributed to low financial inclusion. The 
situation  is  compounded  by  a  weak  and  fragmented  regulatory  framework  and  lack  of 
information on the real supply and demand for credit by low-income populations. As a new entity 
within the MOF, the Bureau of Financial Inclusion Policy and Development, (FIPD) in particular, 
would  benefit  from  strengthened  capacity  to  collect  data  on  the  sector  and  to  oversee 
implementation of a strategy for financial inclusion. 
 
8.    Realizing  the  issues  above,  the  government  is  pursuing  an  inclusive  growth 
development strategy.  Inclusive growth is the underlying concept of the draft 11th national 
economic and social development plan. The plan’s first objective is to build a fairer society to 
ensure social justice, and access to funding and resources to make a living. Policies and market 
rules that encourage easier and affordable access to financial services will at least partly 
address the challenges of achieving more inclusive growth.  
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
9.    The overall impact of the TA will be improved access of the poor to a diverse range of 
financial products and services. The outcome will be an improved regulatory and supervisory 
framework and institutional capacity to support the development of inclusive finance. 
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
10.  Under output 1, using a holistic approach,9 a comprehensive, diagnostic of financial 
inclusion  will  be  completed focusing  on  areas  with  higher  poverty  incidence  in the  north–
northeast, and south–southeast. The project team will propose a methodology for conducting a 
comprehensive financial inclusion diagnostic and will conduct an assessment of the (i) current 
legal, regulatory, and supervisory framework; (ii) supply and demand for microfinance products 
and services, including any gender bias in terms of access and affordability;10 (iii) consumer 
protection; (iv) financial literacy; (v) microinsurance; (vi) remittances; (vii) micropensions; and 
(viii) mobile banking. This will require close collaboration with relevant government agencies 
and extensive consultation on the draft materials with NGOs, community groups, and other key 
stakeholders. For the microinsurance component of the TA, consultants will use the toolkits11 
and  other  methodologies  of  the  Access  to  Insurance  Initiative  (A2II).12 The  results  of  the 
diagnostic will provide the basis for developing a national strategy for financial inclusion (NSFI). 
 
11.  Output 2 includes an approved NSFI accompanied by an implementation plan focusing 
on regulatory and market improvements in microfinance, consumer protection, financial literacy, 
and microinsurance. The TA team will hold a series of government and stakeholder meetings

and the role of a wide range of private and public stakeholders. 
10 This might include lack of property rights, other types of collateral, or other factors that may impede women from

4 
and workshops to develop the draft NSFI and implementation plan.13 Once consensus for the 
draft strategy is achieved, a national stakeholder workshop (or workshops in key regions) will be 
held to include relevant financial institutions, development agencies, NGOs, and academics 
involved in microfinance. The resulting NSFI and implementation plan will be submitted for 
consideration and approval by the government, and a national conference to launch the strategy 
will be held once the plan is approved. 
 
12.   Output  3  is  strengthened  capacity  of the  Bureau  of  Financial  Inclusion  Policy  and 
Development (FIPD) to conduct its supervisory responsibility. A capacity assessment of FIPD’s 
ability to perform its delegated functions for financial inclusion will be followed by a series of 
capacity-building workshops to address needs. The main areas for training are expected to be   
(i) strategy for microfinance,14 (ii) strategy for microinsurance, and (iii) informal debt resolution.  
 
13.  Output 4 is a financial inclusion database installed within FIPD. The TA team will assess 
the requirements for an appropriately structured database for the executing agency to capture 
the supply and demand for financial services on a permanent basis (with data segregated by 
sex and ethnicity).15 It will then identify appropriate systems for implementation, and help install 
and train staff on data flow, system management, and analysis. 
 
14.    Output 5 is implementation of two priority tasks included in the implementation plan. As 
the government has already identified consumer protection and financial literacy as priorities, 
the initial tasks will likely include development of draft consumer protection regulation and the 
rollout of a financial literacy campaign.  
 
15.  By ensuring collaborative dialogue among all stakeholders throughout the diagnostic 
phase,  development  of  a  national  strategy,  and  the  setting  of  realistic  goals,  the  risk  of 
insufficient market response to new financial service opportunities should be mitigated. This will 
also  support  the  realization  of  successful  implementation  of  the  final  NSFI  and  related 
implementation plan within a reasonable time frame. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
16.    The Government has requested $1,500,000 equivalent in financing.  The TA will be 
financed on a grant basis by the Japan Fund for Poverty Reduction and administered by ADB.  
The Government will provide counterpart support in the form of remuneration of counterpart 
staff, office space and meeting venues, furniture, administration support, logistics and other in-
kind contributions.  (See Appendix 2 for the cost estimates and financing plan.) 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
17.  The TA will be implemented over 3 years, from February 2012 to February 2015.16  FPO  
will be the executing agency, while FIPD will be the main point of contact for the TA. Other 
implementing agencies will be the Bank of Thailand, responsible for assisting with regulatory

and  private  sector  entities  engaged  in  microfinance,  development  organizations,  and  gender-balanced

5 
 
and  supervisory  elements  of  the  TA  and  the  Office  of  the  Insurance  Commission  for  the 
microinsurance component. A national steering committee, to oversee development of the NSFI, 
will  be  made  up  of  key  government  agency  representatives  (BAAC,  Bank  of  Thailand, 
Community Development Department, Government Savings Bank, the Ministry of Agriculture 
and Cooperatives, and the Ministry of Social Development and Human Security, MOF, Office of 
the  Insurance  Commission).17 An  advisory  council  will  comprise  external  stakeholders  and 
microfinance  service  providers.  The  consultants,  in  close  collaboration  with  the  executing 
agency, will conduct workshops, training, seminars, conferences, and surveys. 
 
18.  The TA will require seven international consultants (for a total of 32 person-months) and 
five  national  consultants  (for  a  total  of  61  person-months),  with  expertise  in  microfinance 
regulation  and  supervision,  information  system  development,  microinsurance,  consumer 
protection  and  financial  literacy,  and  gender  and  pro-poor  activities.  ADB  will  engage  the 
consultants under a firm using quality- and cost-based selection with 80%–20% quality and cost. 
This will be in accordance with ADB’s Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (2010, as amended 
from time to time). The consultants’ terms of reference are in Appendix 3. The team leader will 
be  responsible  for  all  outputs  consistent  with  the  design  and  monitoring  framework.  The 
consultants will work out of an office provided by FIPD and report to the head of FIPD on day-to-
day matters and to the ADB team leader for all other matters.  
 
19.    In addition to the main outputs, the consultants will submit to ADB and the executing 
agency (i) an inception report 2 weeks after commencement of services; (ii) interim progress 
reports at appropriate stages during TA implementation; (iii) the draft summary final report for 
the overall TA before the conclusion of the contract; and (iv) revised final report 2 weeks after 
receiving and taking into account the comments of, and feedback from, the executing agency, 
other stakeholders, and ADB. All key final output reports and the final summary report of the 
results of the overall TA will be submitted in English and Thai.  
 
20.    The executing agency and ADB review missions will regularly monitor and report on 
major  project  activities.  Consultants’ reports  will  be  presented  in  workshops  and  seminars 
organized for the validation of findings. Reports will be made available on ADB websites in 
English  and  Thai  (if  deemed  feasible  by  ADB  and  the  executing  agency)  and  published 
whenever warranted. Knowledge products will be developed and disseminated as appropriate. 
 
21.  Equipment for use by the TA consultants will be procured by ADB in accordance with 
ADB’s Procurement Guidelines (2010, as amended from time to time) and will be handed over 
at the end of the TA to FPO. The TA proceeds will be disbursed in line with ADB’s Technical 
Assistance Disbursement Handbook (2010, as amended from time to time).18 
 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
22.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved ADB 
administering  technical  assistance  not  exceeding  the  equivalent  of  $1,500,000  to  the 
Government  of  Thailand  to  be  financed  on  a  grant  basis  by  the  Japan  Fund  for  Poverty 
Reduction for the Development of a Strategic Framework for Financial Inclusion, and hereby 
reports this action to the Board.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
1.  The international consultants will work closely with the Bureau of Financial Inclusion 
Policy and Development (FIPD) of the Fiscal Policy Office (FPO) within the Ministry of Finance 
(MOF) and consult frequently with the national strategy for financial inclusion (NSFI) steering 
committee. The national consultants will report to the international consultant acting as team 
leader and, in the latter’s absence, to the director of FIPD. Consultants will be required to 
provide deliverables consistent with the design and monitoring framework activities, outputs, 
and delivery dates. Reports are to be of high quality and produced in English, with copies in 
Thai (as appropriate) by the report delivery dates.   
 
A.  International Consultants 
 
1.  Microfinance  Sector  Development  Specialist  and  Team  Leader                               
(10 person-months) 
 
2.  The specialist and team leader will have a postgraduate degree in banking or finance or 
equivalent and at least 10 years of recognized professional experience in microfinance, focusing 
on microfinance institution regulation, development of national strategies for financial inclusion, 
institutional  reform,  development,  and  project  management.  Experience  in  Southeast  Asia, 
especially knowledge of microfinance in Thailand and work on gender or pro-poor focused 
activities, is preferred. The consultant will (i) assume overall consultant responsibility, and guide 
and manage inputs and outputs of other consultants; (ii) take the lead and assume overall 
responsibility for the diagnostic phase of the technical assistance (TA) and the final diagnostic 
report;  (iii)  facilitate  steering  and  advisory  committee  discussions  throughout  project 
development; (iv) convene and facilitate a series of internal government and multistakeholder 
workshops to develop a draft national strategy for financial inclusion based on the regulatory 
framework assessment; (v) assist in preparing, organizing, and executing a national stakeholder 
workshop(s)  to  discuss  the  draft  strategy  to  include  all  government  agencies  and  other 
stakeholders,  including  financial  institutions,  development  agencies,  nongovernment 
organizations, private sector, academics, and other entities involved in the microfinance sector; 
(vi) work with relevant FIPD staff to finalize the draft national strategy for financial inclusion to 
include an implementation plan for submission to the cabinet for endorsement (assuming overall 
responsibility  for  finalizing  the  report);  and  (vii)  develop  a  plan  for  phase  II  of  the  Asian 
Development Bank (ADB) TA focusing on implementation of recommended regulatory reforms.  
 
2.      Microfinance Regulatory and Supervision Specialist (4 person-months)    
 
3.  The specialist should have a postgraduate degree in law, finance, or business; at least 
10-years  experience  with  microfinance  and  not  less  than  5  years  recognized  professional 
experience working in microfinance regulation and supervision. Experience in Southeast Asia, 
especially knowledge of microfinance in Thailand, is preferable. The consultant will (i) review all 
relevant legislation and regulations related to the provision of financial services to low-income 
people as well as other relevant legislation (including mobile banking), and propose a standard 
definition for microfinance and a system of categorization of microfinance providers for inclusion 
in the Ministry of Finance, Bureau of Financial Inclusion Policy and Development’s database;   
(ii)  develop  recommendations for regulatory  and  supervision  requirements  specific  to  each 
category with reference to international best practice, but with particular focus on the political 
and economic context; (iii) based on regulatory review, assist the Bank of Thailand (BOT) and 
MOF in proposing (for inclusion in the NSFI and implementation plan) new or revised rules and 
regulations; (iv) review operating procedures and systems of microfinance supervision units

10  Appendix 3 
from relevant government agencies, draft and finalize a new operation procedures manual for 
staff of these supervisory units; and (v) review supervision and data reporting requirements for 
each category of microfinance provider, and assist BOT and MOF in improving the supervision 
data management and analysis system.  
 
3.         Microinsurance Development Specialist (Regulatory)  (3 person-months)  
 
4.  The  specialist  will  have  a  postgraduate  degree  in  business  administration,  finance, 
insurance, or a related field with at least 10 years of professional experience including at least  
5 years recognized professional experience in development of microinsurance products and 
services. Experience in Southeast Asia, especially knowledge of Thailand’s microfinance sector, 
is  preferred.  The  consultant  will  (i)  conduct  a  diagnostic  study  on  the  current  insurance 
regulatory framework and provide recommendations for revisions to support the strengthening 
of microinsurance, as part of microfinance services, to meet the risk protection needs of low-
income households; (ii) propose rules and regulations related to current laws on microinsurance 
or any related legislation to promote the outreach and ensure the integrity of microinsurance to 
be included in the NSFI and implementation plan; and (iii) hold capacity-building workshops 
focused on strengthening the capacity of the Office of the Insurance Commission and FIPD to 
conduct delegated activities related to microinsurance.  
 
4.         Microinsurance Development Specialist (Products) (3 person-months)                
 
5.  The  specialist  will  have  a  postgraduate  degree  in  business  administration,  finance, 
insurance, or a related field with at least 10 years of professional experience including at least  
5 years recognized professional experience in development of microinsurance products and 
services. Experience in Southeast Asia, especially knowledge of microfinance in Thailand, is 
preferred. The consultant will (i) conduct a comprehensive diagnostic study on the supply and 
demand of microinsurance products and services for low-income households, (ii) work with the 
international microinsurance development specialist (regulatory) to formulate and recommend 
relevant rules and regulations to encourage insurance companies or other financial service 
providers (as allowed by the law) to offer microinsurance products and services to be included 
in  the  NSFI  and  implementation  plan,  and  (iii)  work  with  the  international  microinsurance 
development specialist (regulatory) to hold a series of capacity-building workshops focused on 
strengthening the capacity of FIPD to conduct its delegated activities related to microinsurance.  
 
5.         Information System Development Specialist (2 person-months)  
 
6.  The specialist will have a minimum of 7 years of professional experience, including 
experience in the development and management of information systems, which include data on 
microfinance.  Experience  in  Southeast  Asia  is  preferred.  The  consultant  will  (i)  conduct  a 
thorough assessment of the requirements for developing a database for FPO’s FIPD to capture 
the supply and demand for financial services; (ii) oversee the work of the national information 
system development specialist to design or adapt an existing database management system 
and  assist  in  installing  and  operationalizing  the  system;  and  (iii)  oversee  the  design  of  a 
database manual and conduct training on the effective data information management for FIPD 
staff and management, as well as microfinance providers who will submit information to the 
database.

Appendix 3  11 
6.         Consumer Protection Specialist (5 person-months) 
 
7.  The specialist will have a postgraduate degree in business administration, finance, or a 
related  field  and  at  least  10  years  professional  experience,  including  experience  in  the 
development of consumer protection products and services. Experience in Southeast Asia and 
working on gender or pro-poor focused activities is preferred. The consultant will (i) conduct 
desk research on a consumer protection legal and regulatory framework for financial services 
internationally  in  order  to  propose  a  benchmark  for  consumer  protection  appropriate  to 
Thailand’s microfinance services; (ii) conduct a gap analysis of existing consumer protection 
regulation and compare its adequacy against the established benchmark; and (iii) propose 
recommendations for addressing gaps identified, taking into consideration the new benchmark 
proposed by the study, international best practice, the Thai context, consumer welfare and 
market development dynamics to be included in the NSFI; and (iv) once the NSFI is formally 
adopted, develop an implementation plan for needed legislative and financial institution reforms.  
 
7.         Financial Literacy Specialist (5 person-months) 
 
8.  The specialist will have a post-graduate degree in business administration, finance, or 
related  field;  at  least  10  years  professional  experience  in  microfinance,  including  5  years 
experience in financial literacy and experience working on gender or pro-poor focused activities; 
and have a good understanding of microfinance in Thailand. Experience in Southeast Asia and 
knowledge of the Thai language is preferred. The consultant will (i) in close collaboration with 
the international information system development specialist and staff from FIPD, BOT, and the 
Bank for Agriculture and Agricultural Cooperatives (BAAC), research current financial literacy 
among low-income populations in Thailand; (ii) conduct a gap analysis of existing financial 
literacy among low-income populations in Thailand, existing financial literacy plans and goals for 
financial  literacy;  (iii)  develop  a  standard  for  financial  literacy  in  microfinance  services;  
(iv)  propose recommendations for  addressing gaps  identified,  taking  into consideration the 
standard proposed, international best practice, and the political and economic context to be 
included in the NSFI; (v) once the NSFI is formally adopted, develop a specific implementation 
plan for financial literacy to be included in the overall NSFI implementation plan; and (vi) design 
an information exchange campaign ensuring that 50% of the people reached are women and 
that gender issues such as women's needs, opportunities, and benefits related to financial 
inclusion are integrated in campaign materials and that the campaign outreach is conducted at 
appropriate times to maximize women's access and attendance.  
 
B.  National Consultants 
 
1.  Microfinance Specialist (12 person-months) 
 
9.  The specialist will have a degree in business administration, economics, or a related 
discipline  and  at  least  5  years  professional  experience  in  microfinance.  Knowledge  of 
microfinance in Thailand is required. Experience in working for international aid organizations 
and work on gender or pro-poor focused activities is preferred. The consultant will (i) assist the 
international microfinance sector development specialist and team leader with all aspects of the 
terms of reference as required; (ii) collect and analyze required data and information, and make 
these  available  in  English  in  an  organized,  readable  form;  (iii)  help  prepare  guidelines, 
mandates,  manuals,  training  materials,  and  delivery  of  workshops  and  training,  including 
translation of documents and interpretation; and (iv) undertake other tasks necessary for the 
efficient implementation of the TA as may reasonably be required by the team leader.

12  Appendix 3 
2.  Information System Development Specialist (3 person-months) 
 
10.  The  specialist  will  have  a  minimum  of  5  years  professional  experience,  including 
experience in the development and management of information systems that include data in the 
finance sector. Experience in microfinance is preferred. The consultant will (i) work with the 
international information system development specialist to conduct a thorough assessment of 
the requirements for developing a database for FPO’s FIPD to capture the supply and demand 
for financial services; (ii) work with the international information system development specialist 
to identify an appropriate data collection system; (iii) design or adapt an existing database 
management system and assist in installing and operationalizing the system; and (iv) along with 
the international information system development specialist, design a database manual and 
conduct training on effective data information management for FIPD staff and management, as 
well as microfinance providers who will submit information to the database.  
 
3.  Consumer Protection Specialist (5 person-months) 
 
11.  The specialist will have a postgraduate degree in business administration, finance, or 
related  field;  at  least  5  years  professional  experience  in  microfinance,  including  3  years 
experience in consumer protection; and a good understanding of microfinance in Thailand. 
Experience in Southeast Asia and knowledge of the Thai language is preferred. The consultant 
will (i) in close collaboration with the international consumer protection specialist as well as staff 
from FIPD, BOT, and BAAC support research on a consumer protection legal and regulatory 
framework; (ii) support the conduct of a gap analysis of existing consumer protection regulation 
and compare its adequacy against the established benchmark; (iii) work with the international 
consumer protection specialist to propose recommendations for addressing any gaps identified, 
taking into consideration the new benchmark proposed by the study, international best practice, 
the Thai context, consumer welfare, and market development dynamics to be included in the 
NSFI;  and  (iv)  once  the  NSFI  is  formally  adopted,  contribute  to  development  of  an 
implementation plan to map out legislative and financial institution reforms needed.  
 
4.  Financial Literacy Specialist (5 person-months) 
 
12.  The specialist will have a postgraduate degree in business administration, finance, or 
related field and at least 5 years professional experience in microfinance, including 3 years 
experience  in  financial  literacy;  and  must  have  a  good  understanding  of  microfinance  in 
Thailand. Experience in Southeast Asia and knowledge of Thai language is preferred. The 
consultant will (i) in close collaboration with the international specialist on financial literacy as 
well as staff from FIPD, BOT, and BAAC research current financial literacy among low-income 
populations; (ii) support the conduct of a gap analysis of existing financial literacy among low-
income populations and a  set goal for financial literacy; (iii) in close collaboration with the 
microfinance  regulatory  and  supervision  specialist  and  international  specialist  on  financial 
literacy, support the development of a standard for financial literacy in Thailand’s microfinance 
services;  (iv)  work  with  the  international  specialist  on  financial  literacy  to  propose 
recommendations  for  addressing  gaps  identified,  taking  into  consideration  the  standard 
proposed, international best practice, and the Thai political and economic context to be included 
in the NSFI; (v) once the NSFI is formally adopted, develop a specific implementation plan for 
financial literacy to be included in the overall NSFI implementation plan; and (vi) design an 
information exchange campaign ensuring that 50% of the people reached are women and that 
gender issues such as  women's needs, opportunities, and benefits related to financial inclusion 
are  integrated  in  campaign  materials  and  that  the  campaign  outreach  is  conducted  at 
appropriate times to maximize women's access and attendance.

Appendix 3  13 
 
5.         National Project Assistant (36 person-months) 
 
13.  The national project assistant will have a degree in business administration, economics, 
or a related discipline and at least 3 years recognized professional experience in the areas of 
project assistance and management. Experience in working for international aid organizations is 
preferred. The consultant will (i) assist in arranging and organizing meetings for the TA activities 
and ADB missions; (ii) assist in preparing materials for reports, meetings, and workshops, 
including  translation  of  materials  and  document  production;  (iii)  provide  written  and  oral 
translation  from  English  to  Thai  and  Thai  to  English  as  required  including  participation  in 
meetings and workshops; (iv) provide assistance to the TA consultants on specific technical 
matters as requested; (v) provide assistance to the TA consultants in administrative matters 
including travel and visa arrangements, maintenance of hard and soft copy files including back-
ups, and general office administration; (vi) contribute as required to the inception, quarterly 
progress, midterm, draft final, and final reports; and (vii) carry out other work in connection with 
the project as may be reasonably requested by the TA consultants.
